channel.title: Comprehensible Russian Podcast | Learn Russian with Max
channel.description:
Learn the Russian language? Is listening important when you learn a language? Yes it is! You can pick up words and see how the language works, but... If the information you are listening to is not clear for you, if you cannot understand what was said, does it make any sense? No! Absolutely not! This podcast provides you different kinds of topics in Russian in a very comprehensible way. Repetitions, synonyms, explanations and slow speed of speech will be your bridge to understand the real Russian Language. Transcripts: https://russianwithmax.com
https://www.youtube.com/c/RussianWithMax

item.title: 054 - How to get a better job (Dialogue)
item.description:
Today we have a dialogue in Russian with Julia. 

We discuss job hunting, creating resume, and how to prepare for an interview. Julia has a large experience in recruitment and share with us some good ideas.

Podcast transcripts: https://www.russianwithmax.com/

item.title: 051 - Samovar and Rituals in our life (Conversation with Mitya)
item.description:
Today we have a Russian conversation with a friend of mine named Mitya. 

What's the history of the traditional Russian samovar?

Why ceremonies and rituals are so important in our modern life?


Prepare for real Russian with lots of slang and common phrases ;) 

Transcripts:  https://www.russianwithmax.com/

item.title: 048 - Do Russians believe in superstitions?
item.description:
What do Russians think about superstitions?

How they affect us?

How they affect our daily life?

I collected 11 most common Russian (probably not only Russian) superstitions and want to share them with you. I am going to tell you my prospective on that as well.


The lesson pack I mentioned in the episode:

https://www.russianwithmax.com/product/russian-through-stories-lesson-pack/

item.title: 046 - Don't waste your thinking!
item.description:
Greetings!

In the first part of this episode I'm going to answer a question about 2 particles "-—Ç–æ" and "-–∫–∞".

In the second part we will talk about how to not waste our thinking and increase our productivity.

Let's jump in!


Transcripts:

https://www.russianwithmax.com/

item.title: 045 ‚Äì We Are All Getting Dumber!
item.description:
Today we discuss some thoughts  from a book called "–ß–µ—Ä—Ç–æ–≥–∏ —Ä–∞–∑—É–º–∞. –£–±–µ–π –≤ —Å–µ–±–µ –∏–¥–∏–æ—Ç–∞" –ê–Ω–¥—Ä–µ—è –ö—É—Ä–ø–∞—Ç–æ–≤–∞.

It's a cool book I started to read and just right away I faced lots of interesting ideas and fact in terms of how our thinking works and why we getting dumber. 

What cases destruction of thinking?

Why simplification is not a good idea?

Why we can't focus for a long time?

Let's find out what doctor Kurpatov says...

 

 Transcripts and some scientific terms:

https://www.russianwithmax.com/

item.title: 042 - Russian people in cities and villages
item.description:
–ü—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç-–ø—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç!^^

I recorded this episode sitting by the side of a big lake during my last trip up to the north from Saint-Petersburg.

I came up with this podcast idea when I was talking to locals in a small northern village. I was pleasantly surprised by their openness and hospitality.

 

I'm always glad to hear your stories!


P.S. In the episode I was wrong in the beginning calling the city –ü—Ä–∏–æ–∑–µ—Ä—Å–∫, it's called –ü–µ—Ç—Ä–æ–∑–∞–≤–æ–¥—Å–∫.


Transcripts and vocabulary section:

 https://www.russianwithmax.com 

 –ú—É–∑—ã–∫–∞: –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º –ê–Ω—É—Ö–∏–Ω (aka Gudimir)

item.title: 041 - I don't have time for that
item.description:
Why we always have no time for something?

Is this because we really do a lot of stuff that bring us happiness?

Or it's just a form of avoiding ourselves, suffering, and lack of prioritization?

In today's Russian podcast I'm trying to discuss this questions with...ahem, myself as usual. However Max (the second one xD) has got some good thoughts about it and would be happy to hear your experience! 


Transcripts and vocabulary section:

 https://www.russianwithmax.com 


 –ú—É–∑—ã–∫–∞: –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º –ê–Ω—É—Ö–∏–Ω (aka Gudimir)

item.title: 038 - Fake life
item.description:
In this Episode of our Russian Podcast I share with you my thoughts on why the virtual life sucks.

We want more comfort.

We want ease.

We tend to have things simpler and get services faster.

But have we ever thought why faster is better? Do not we lose ourselves and reality in this sea of binary signals?


Let's get our as**s outside and discuss it learning a few cool vocabulary words and phrases at the same time.


links to the videos I mentioned:

I came back to my little house in Russia:

https://youtu.be/KTQ-w7ghnZk

Buying On The Internet (Russian Vocabulary):

https://youtu.be/bVR7tB9Fb3s

How we see the world and other people? (Russian listening practice):

https://youtu.be/e6NzDPaPrLQ


Transcripts and a few photos:

https://www.russianwithmax.com/ 


–ú—É–∑—ã–∫–∞: –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º –ê–Ω—É—Ö–∏–Ω (aka Gudimir)

item.title: 037 - Fear
item.description:
No, no, no...

I'm not gonna tell you about darkness, vampires, and horror films... although it sounds interesting :D

Today I want to talk about my recent trip to Moscow and what I experienced being an 'technical engineer' during a preparation for Julia's summer camp.

At the end we will discuss a bit such things as 'What does fear mean?" and 'How it ruins our daily life, ahah'!

Let's begin!

item.title: 036 - Media, Mind control, World government and...
item.description:
I recently met my uncle who lives in Germany and our talks took me to this monologue.

Where are we going?

Who stands behind all this political crap?

Does the world government exist?

You will not find answers for those questions, however I invite you to virtually discuss them and of course learn a few cool and new Russian words and phrases :)

item.title: 031 - What schools never teach you! Chat in Russian with Julia
item.description:
Hi all!

We continue with our education topic, but today we have a guest named Julia who we are going to talk about informal education with.

What is 'informal education'? Why we need changes?

What problems do we find in traditional educational system?

What new methods do we have and how 21-century teacher will look like? You will know from this Russian dialogue.

Learn Russian, get new knowledge, and have fun!

Lots of love,

your Max!

 

Podcast transcripts:  https://russianwithmax.com

item.title: 030 ‚Äì Less stuff less stress. Minimalism
item.description:
Hi there! I'm happy to have you here!

This episode of our Slow Russian Podcast is about minimalism. We probably need 10 episodes to cover this topic, but I'll just share with you my thoughts. I hope you'll enjoy it and learn new interesting Russian words and daily expressions.

I'd also glad to hear from you in the comments and... don't miss a competition (oh, sounds so serious, in fact it's more like fun writing exercise for you:) at the end of the episode.

Lots of love and let's get started!:)


P.S. Thank you all for your iTunes rating! It really helps going forward! Rate on iTunes

item.title: 029 - American Dream, Russian Dream and alternatives
item.description:
Hi all!

In this episode I want to discuss some 'alternative' ways of living.

There are some stereotypes about the American Dream as if it's filled up with materialistic ideas and so forth, but in fact we do have the same concepts in Russia, I mean this tendency to get more, to have bigger houses, more expensive cars and so on. 

Communism crushed, however some people still want to build communes and they have had this idea since... 1960!


Some links I promised to give you:


A family went living off-grid: 

https://vk.com/familykatkovy

A man started living in an abandoned village:

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l6jZdWIqjlc 


Transcripts:  https://www.russianwithmax.com 


–ú—É–∑—ã–∫–∞: –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º –ê–Ω—É—Ö–∏–Ω (–≥—É—Å–ª–∏)

item.title: 028 - Family happiness... or disaster?
item.description:
"All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way. "

That was the beginning of the Anna Karenina novel by L. Tolstoy.

What family problems are there in Russia? 

What kind of relationships do we need to cultivate? 

Should children live with their parents or they should leave?

In this podcast we will talk about those things and of course learn a few new Russian words and expressions.

Let's begin!:) 


Transcripts: https://www.russianwithmax.com

Instagram: @russianwithmax

item.title: 026 - They want to isolate Russian internet. WTF?
item.description:
This time in our Comprehensible Russian Podcast I'd like to tell you about one new Russian bill called "internet isolation". 

They tried to block Telegram last year, but failed. 

What is this about? An attempt to make the Ru-net independent? Or create a new 'Great Chinese Firewall' in Russia? Let's dive into it.


Transcripts:

https://www.russianwithmax.com

item.title: 024 - I want a revolution in Russia!
item.description:
–ü—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç –≤—Å–µ–º!

 "You're either with us, or against us" - The slogan of the October Revolution.


 We had a lot of revolutions in Russia. But I'm sure we need a brand new one! Follow me and in this episode of our Russian podcast I will tell you why... and how :) 


Since last episode I've decided to put some "vocabulary part" in the transcripts, so you can find difficult-word translation in there.

item.title: 023 - Do we really need education?!
item.description:
–ü—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç –≤—Å–µ–º!

Today I want to talk about education in general. In Russia we still have the idea that if you want to succeed, you have to have a higher education. However, our life is changing, and many young people cannot find a decent job after 4-5 years of study. 

What is the problem? 

Do we really need education?

What skills should we have to be successful?

What was the situation in the USSR? 

Let's discuss it!


Transcripts:

https://www.russianwithmax.com

item.title: üìñ Russian Book Club | Three little pigs
item.description:
We start reading in Russian! Hooray! This is the first book called The three little pigs and today we will take a half of it.

This is a short HQ audio version of the YouTube video:

https://youtu.be/i0A4OvGQIs4

Here's the link for text:

http://www.planetaskazok.ru/smihalkovsth/triporosenkamihalkov

My plan:

I choose one short Russian book for reading (or a tale \ story, etc) and give you the full text of it. Then during the live session I explain some difficult words and give you the main idea of the story \ book \ part, so you start reading prepared.

I also upload the HQ audio version of each video to my Comprehensible Russian Podcast therefore you'll be able to listen to the audio as many times as you need.

This is our first episode so I'm open for your suggestions and questions. Let me know what you like and what really helps! I'm going to improve the content and will definitely  change something in the future!

Music by –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º –ê–Ω—É—Ö–∏–Ω (aka Gudimir)

item.title: 021 - My way back to Russia and what I feel about it
item.description:
In this episode of our slow Russian Podcast I decided to walk around the place I live in Saint Petersburg and make a live recording of my thoughts. I am going to tell you how I got to Russia and how I feel about moving here from China.

This podcast is a kind of improvisation and has real spoken Russian. It's slightly adapted for better comprehension.


I mentioned a video from my YouTube "Learn Russian VLog" series and here's the link:

item.title: 019 - How to travel in Russia without money
item.description:
–ü—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç, –º–æ–∏ –¥–æ—Ä–æ–≥–∏–µ –∏ –∑–∞–º–µ—á–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ!

Today in our Slow and Comprehensible Russian podcast I'm going to talk about my experience of traveling in Russia with almost no money.

I started travelling this way 9 years ago and visited lots of wonderful places in Russia (and other world).

Is it easy to travel this way? Where did I sleep? How were the drivers who picked me up?

I'll try to answer these questions and hope you will find some new and useful vocabulary to improve your Russian!


Transcripts for the podcast: https://www.russianwithmax.com

item.title: 013 - Russian TPRS lesson - Irrational thinking
item.description:
This is a TRPS Russian lesson. I tried a new format for our Russian podcast with storytelling and question answering. I'm sure that this method is very effective if you want to learn spoken Russian and think in Russian. However, you should decide yourself what works better for you and if you enjoy this episode and find it helpful let me know at learn@russianwithmax.com and I'll do more stuff like this in the future.

Go to my website and get your full Russian membership lesson right away: https://www.russianwithmax.com 

At the the bottom-right corner you'll see a form. Enter your email and start exploring a wonderful story about Siberian vast.

item.title: 007 - How to acquire a language, Krashen's hypothesis
item.description:
Hey there! Who is Steven Krashen and what are his hypothesis? Today we will talk about the general idea of Krashen's second-language acquisition theory. 

–ü—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç–∏–∫–∏! –ö—Ç–æ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–π –°—Ç–∏–≤–µ–Ω –ö—Ä–∞—à–µ–Ω –∏ —á—Ç–æ –∑–∞ –≥–∏–ø–æ—Ç–µ–∑—ã –æ–Ω –≤—ã–¥–≤–Ω—É–ª? –°–µ–≥–æ–¥–Ω—è –º—ã –ø–æ–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏–º –æ–± –æ–±—â–µ–π –∏–¥–µ–µ —Ç–µ–æ—Ä–∏–∏ –æ–≤–ª–∞–¥–µ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –∏–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º —è–∑—ã–∫–æ–º –°—Ç–∏–≤–µ–Ω–∞ –ö—Ä–∞—à–µ–Ω–∞. 


Free books by Stephen D Krashen: Principles and Practice in Second Language Acquisition: 

http://www.sdkrashen.com/content/books/principles_and_practice.pdf 


Second Language Acquisition and Second Language Learning: 

http://www.sdkrashen.com/content/books/sl_acquisition_and_learning.pdf

item.description:
Hi there!

Today I'm going to read you some news in Russian and afterwards I'll explain the vocabulary words! It's a longer podcast, but I hope you'll enjoy it! 

Transcripts: https://www.russianwithmax.com/ 


Here's the text:

–†–æ—Å—Å–∏–π—Å–∫–∏–µ –≤–ª–∞—Å—Ç–∏ –æ–±—Å—É–¥–∏–ª–∏ –≤–Ω–µ–¥—Ä–µ–Ω–∏–µ —ç–ª–µ–∫—Ç—Ä–æ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö –ø–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç–æ–≤ ‚Äî –≤–ø–µ—Ä–≤—ã–µ —ç—Ç–∞ –∏–¥–µ—è –ø–æ–¥–Ω–∏–º–∞–ª–∞—Å—å –µ—â—ë –≤ 2013 –≥–æ–¥—É. –¢–µ–ø–µ—Ä—å –ø–µ—Ä–µ—Ö–æ–¥ –Ω–∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∏–µ –¥–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã –∑–∞–ø–ª–∞–Ω–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω –Ω–∞ 2021 –≥–æ–¥, –∞ —Å–æ–æ—Ç–≤–µ—Ç—Å—Ç–≤—É—é—â–∏–π –∑–∞–∫–æ–Ω–æ–ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –±—ã—Ç—å —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–Ω –¥–æ –∫–æ–Ω—Ü–∞ —ç—Ç–æ–≥–æ –≥–æ–¥–∞. –ü–æ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤, —Ç–∞–∫–æ–π –ø–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç –±—É–¥–µ—Ç –ø–æ—Ö–æ–∂ –Ω–∞ –±–∞–Ω–∫–æ–≤—Å–∫—É—é –∫–∞—Ä—Ç—É —Å —á–∏–ø–æ–º –∏ –ø–æ–∑–≤–æ–ª–∏—Ç –ø–æ–ª—É—á–∞—Ç—å –≥–æ—Å—É–¥–∞—Ä—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏ –∫–æ–º–º–µ—Ä—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ —É—Å–ª—É–≥–∏. –û–Ω –æ–±—ä–µ–¥–∏–Ω–∏—Ç –≤ —Å–µ–±–µ –ø–∞—Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç, –°–ù–ò–õ–° –∏ –≤–æ–¥–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å—Å–∫–∏–µ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∞ –∏ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç —Ö—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—Ç—å —Å–ª–µ–ø–æ–∫ –ª–∏—Ü–∞ –¥–ª—è —Ä–∞—Å–ø–æ–∑–Ω–∞–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è, –æ—Ç–ø–µ—á–∞—Ç–∫–∏ –ø–∞–ª—å—Ü–µ–≤, —ç–ª–µ–∫—Ç—Ä–æ–Ω–Ω—É—é –ø–æ–¥–ø–∏—Å—å –∏ –∫–æ–¥ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–∞ –∫ —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–æ–≤–æ–º—É –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–∏–ª—é –≤–ª–∞–¥–µ–ª—å—Ü–∞.

item.title: 001 - About this Russian podcast and me
item.description:
Hello, everyone! This is the first episode of my Comprehensible Russian Podcast! Today I'm going to talk about myself, this Russian podcast and its idea. I hope you'll enjoy the show! :)

This podcast is for Russian learners who want to listen to understandable and meaningful audio content in Russian with transcripts. It's designed to push you into the Russian language for 20-25 minutes so you can start feeling the language by discovering many things as my daily life and routines, some problems that we have in Russian, interesting Russian people, facts, and Russian culture.

I want to cover different topics in order to build your vocabulary foundation in the natural way.

I want you to forget about language learning while listening! I want you to enjoy the content at first and only afterwards read the text and start dealing with some difficult words and phrases (vocabulary reference is included in every new transcript).

Put it in your daily basis! Practice your listening! Repeat after me some phrases you like to let them stuck in your mind and improve your pronunciation. 

Enjoy!

Have fun!

Ask questions and feel free to communicate with other learners in the comments!

Let's begin;)

Transcripts: https://www.russianwithmax.com

–ú—É–∑—ã–∫–∞(–ì—É—Å–ª–∏): –ú–∞–∫—Å–∏–º –ê–Ω—É—Ö–∏–Ω (aka Gudimir)
